DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

White House Economic Adviser Hassett said US is still working hard on reaching a deal with China but differences remain. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK House Speaker Bercow has blocked a third meaningful vote unless the government has made changes to its Brexit deal and said that lawmakers have expressed concern regarding more than one vote on PM May's Brexit deal. (Newswires)

EU official said Bercow's announcement, which essentially prevents a third meaningful vote unless there are changes, has made an extension "more likely", with the focus on the political declaration according to BuzzFeed's Alberto Nardelli. (BuzzFeed)

UK Solicitor General Buckland said there are ways around the speaker's ruling, with prorogation (discontinuing Parliament, without dissolving it) being an option for the government, while he also commented that the UK is in a constitutional crisis. (Newswires)

UK Brexit minister Kwarteng said PM May will write to EU's Tusk setting out possible extensions the UK is seeking at the EU council and that it will be either a technical extension or a longer one. (Guardian)

UK PM May spokesman said if a vote can be passed this week, a short technical extension will be sought, alternatively if a vote is not won this week a longer extension will be sought with UK partaking in European elections. The spokesman also commented that the government is still preparing for a no deal Brexit but negotiations are over. (Newswires)

One Minister close to PM May expects the EU to grant an Article 50 extension of nine-months maximum, which would require the UK to take part in European elections according to ITV's Peston. Peston also noted that almost 100% are certain that there will be no deal between the DUP and government this week and a vote on UK PM May's deal is highly likely next week. Furthermore, 23 Brexiteer MPs lead by Owen Paterson will reportedly continue voting against PM May's deal rather than abstaining, making it "impossible" for her to get it through. (ITV)

UK could be refused a Brexit extension if PM May fails to get an agreement in the HoC, according to reports citing EU's Verhofstadt. (Evening Standard)

UK reached a post-Brexit trade agreement with Iceland and Norway. (Newswires)

ECB's de Guindos (Neutral) said the effects of the idiosyncratic factors currently weighing on economic growth are expected to unwind, while he added that GDP growth in the euro area is expected to remain sound in the medium term and that interest rates are expected to remain at their present levels “at least through the end of 2019”. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

EIA sees US total shale regions production up by 85k BPD at 8.593mln BPD in April (vs 90k projected rise in March). (Newswires) 

Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih said they do not think a balanced market will happen in H1 2019 and the Kingdom will swing production if needed, while Al-Falih expects inventory to drop between now and May and will not leave production unguided in H2 2019. (Newswires)

OPEC statement stated that all countries at the OPEC JMMC meeting said they will exceed their voluntary output adjustments in the coming months and that the JMMC sees overall output cut conformity in February at 90%. In related news, OPEC sources stated the JMMC panel recommends no meeting in April, while the OPEC Non-OPEC JMMC is to include Iraq, UAE, Malaysia, Nigeria and Kazakhstan as new members. (Newswires) 

MARKET RECAP

Boeing (BA) begun the week again on a downbeat, as US federal authorities have begun probing its manufacturing process for 737 MAX jets. Facebook (FB) was a weight on the tech sector after having a price target slash at BAML and a downgrade at Needham. Edwards Lifesciences (EW) surged on promising results from one of its aortic devices, however, competitors Medtronic (MDT), Boston Scientific (BSX) and Becton Dickinson (BDX) all traded lower after the FDA posted a letter expressing concern on the use of paclitaxel-coated products. Disney (DIS) and Fox (FOXA) traded lower following Fox’s shareholders vote on the consideration they would prefer for its acquisition. Marriott (MAR) opened higher after providing guidance as part of its three-year plan. Worldpay (WP) rallied on the announcement Fidelity (FIS) would be acquiring it in a cash and stock deal. Caesars (CZR) surged and Eldorado Resorts (ERI) dipped following reports the two companies were in preliminary merger talks. Newell Brands (NWL) traded higher on announcing the spin off of one of its units. Apple (AAPL) was supported by unveiling of its new iPads. Oilfield services stocks such as Halliburton (HAL) and Schlumberger (SLB) were outperformers. Kraft Heinz (KHC) underperformed after receiving a Nasdaq notice for a delayed 10-K filing. US T-note futures (M9) settled 4 ticks lower at 122-27. SPX +0.37% at 2833, NDX +0.26% at 7326, DJI +0.25% at 25914.

Yields were little changed on Monday, ahead of the FOMC on Wednesday, which is expected to be a dovish update, where forecasts are cut, the central bank announces the end of QT, while reiterating data-dependence and patience. The curve was biased towards small flattening, at settlement, having traded a lot of the early part of the session slightly steeper. There was little on the data docket or speakers, with the focus on flows; some had suggested that CTAs sold the uptick, though the move lower couldn’t gain traction after real money buyers came in on at the long-end. Strengthening equities tried to influence the action, though volumes were low, and even equities themselves were subject to choppy trading at times.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 18 March 2019: Markets quietly prepare for big week; Speaker blocks May’s MV3 in current form
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

US MARKET WRAP 18 March 2019: Markets quietly prepare for big week; Speaker blocks May’s MV3 in current form.

 

* SNAP SHOT: Equities up, dollar flat, Treasuries down, crude up.

* REAR VIEW: Xi-Trump meeting potentially delayed again; Brexit MV3 blocked in current form; OPEC+ meeting postponed.

* AHEAD: RBA mins; Germany ZEW; UK labour data; API inventories; BOJ mins; Riksbank’s Skingsley; earnings FDX

 

* TRADE: Reports over the weekend indicated that the much-anticipated Trump-Xi meeting is likely to be postponed till June, after previously being postponed till April, as differences remain both between the US and China as well as between officials in the White House. White House Economic Adviser Hassett said the US is still working hard on reaching a deal with China but differences remain. US Agricultural Secretary Perdue said talks remain dynamic, and that China has made very attractive offers for agricultural purchases. Away from the US, a draft statement for the EU & China April summit revealed the two powers are to agree to conclude a bilateral investment pact in 2020, they will list the main barriers to trade by this summer, and to set removal deadlines by 2020; the summit will also see them commit to begin negotiations on industrial subsidies, and a new set of guidelines for government-supported export credits.

* ANALYSIS: The market has calmly digested reports that a Trump/Xi meeting to wrap up a trade deal may be pushed back to June (meeting was originally expected end-March, and just last week, we were guided towards a delayed April meeting). We have come to expect that any pushing back of the trade timetable was negative for risk assets, but we haven’t seen any of that on Monday, where risk assets mostly saw upside. Perhaps the measured response is a result of the dovish central bank expectations for this week (ex the Norges Bank, which is expected to lift rates by 25bps), with the Fed expected to dial-down its growth forecasts, end its balance sheet run off, while remaining data dependent; BOE seen standing pat, SNB will probably mirror the ECB’s recent dovishness. This would follow a softening in the tone of growth forecasts from major central banks and institutions, which analysts are minded to believe will continue to support risk. Barclays’ analysts still warn, however, that if recent experience is a guide, support from dovish central banks has done little to offset the drag from weaker growth. Accordingly, it is worth noting the tone of flash PMI data, on the slate for the latter part of the week. A decent set of data, may once again start leading some to question the dovish prices, given the recent stabilisation in Chinese and European data, as well as the data surprise indices which have once again been ticking up in March.

* BREXIT: The week began with the likelihood of a third meaningful vote on UK PM May’s Brexit deal being majorly diminished, where HoC speaker John Bercow said he would not allow the vote to go in for a third round unless there were changes made to the deal, effectively ruling out the government’s ability to play politics in order to muster together additional votes for May’s deal. Consequentially, an EU official has said an extension is now more likely, with the focus now on the political declaration. Analysts suggest Bercow’s ruling will have helped May by giving her the time needed to make changes to her meaningful vote and to gain the needed supporters.

* WTI FUTURES (J9) SETTLE $0.57 HIGHER AT $59.09; BRENT (K9) SETTLE $0.38 HIGHER AT $67.54. Crude edged higher on Monday in the midst of OPEC+ deciding to hold back their April meeting and bullish supply cut news on the back of the OPEC JMMC meeting held over the weekend. The oil cartel has postponed its previously suggested April meeting till June 25th-26th before it makes any adjustments to output targets, Saudi’s Energy Minister Al-Falih confirmed; “the decision to wait for more data makes sense in our view, particularly since Russian production isn’t expected to decline to its 2019 limit until April,” analysts at Citigroup commented on the decision. “Gasoline futures continue to lead the wider petroleum complex higher”, the bank said, “supported by an assortment of refinery outages, including the 130,500 bpd fluid catalytic cracker at the Bayway refinery in Linden, New Jersey, a key source of supply to the New York Harbor delivery point for RBOB futures… bullish for the gasoline market and also supportive for the market overall.” Elsewhere, all countries at the OPEC JMMC meeting said they will exceed their voluntary output adjustments in the coming months, seeing overall output cut conformity in February at 90%; Al-Falih added that he expects OPEC+ to reach full compliance within weeks and sees an extension of the supply cut agreement through 2019. The prodigal Libya NOC said output has risen to 1.2mln BPD, with the El Sharara oilfield (capacity 300K BPD) currently pumping 260K BPD.

* SPX +0.37% at 2833, NDX +0.26% at 7326, DJI +0.25% at 25914. SECTORS: Energy +1.40%, Materials +0.16%, Industrials +0.87%, Cons Discretionary +1.05%, Cons Staples +0.28%, Healthcare -0.15%, Financials +1.04%, Tech +0.41%, Telecoms -0.80%, Utilities -0.40%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Boeing (BA) begun the week again on a downbeat, as US federal authorities have begun probing its manufacturing process for 737 MAX jets. Facebook (FB) was a weight on the tech sector after having a price target slash at BAML and a downgrade at Needham. Edwards Lifesciences (EW) surged on promising results from one of its aortic devices, however, competitors Medtronic (MDT), Boston Scientific (BSX) and Becton Dickinson (BDX) all traded lower after the FDA posted a letter expressing concern on the use of paclitaxel-coated products. Disney (DIS) and Fox (FOXA) traded lower following Fox’s shareholders vote on the consideration they would prefer for its acquisition. Marriott (MAR) opened higher after providing guidance as part of its three-year plan. Worldpay (WP) rallied on the announcement Fidelity (FIS) would be acquiring it in a cash and stock deal. Caesars (CZR) surged and Eldorado Resorts (ERI) dipped following reports the two companies were in preliminary merger talks. Newell Brands (NWL) traded higher on announcing the spin off of one of its units. Apple (AAPL) was supported by unveiling of its new iPads. Oilfield services stocks such as Halliburton (HAL) and Schlumberger (SLB) were outperformers. Kraft Heinz (KHC) underperformed after receiving a Nasdaq notice for a delayed 10-K filing.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLED 4 TICKS LOWER AT 122-27. Yields were little changed on Monday, ahead of the FOMC on Wednesday, which is expected to be a dovish update, where forecasts are cut, the central bank announces the end of QT, while reiterating data-dependence and patience. The curve was biased towards small flattening, at settlement, having traded a lot of the early part of the session slightly steeper. There was little on the data docket or speakers, with the focus on flows; some had suggested that CTAs sold the uptick, though the move lower couldn’t gain traction after real money buyers came in on at the long-end. Strengthening equities tried to influence the action, though volumes were low, and even equities themselves were subject to choppy trading at times.

* USD, EMFX: The buck pared back losses incurred through Asia- and early European trade, and we are more or less flat entering APAC trade. Clearly the major catalyst this week is the FOMC meeting on Wednesday, where the central bank is expected to cut growth and inflation forecasts, lower the 'dots' and reiterate commitment to a data-dependent policy approach in the framework of patience; it is also expected to confirm the end of QT this year. This should generally be a favourable backdrop for risk assets, analysts have said, particularly, the EMFX complex. BlackRock's strategists note that EM markets could end up recouping the losses incurred last year: "All the key challenges emerging markets had last year have been surmounted and the global liquidity has returned to emerging markets’ favor," BlackRock's EM strategist said (rate differentials vs US, dovish central bank policy, China liquidity injections, etc). BlackRock notes that EM equities are correlated to the weaker buck, and the strategist recommended Mexican, Argentine and Indonesian stocks. "When a currency weakens or bond yields increase, typically equities go down, so if we've become positive on a currency, firstly a perfect way to express it is through an equity. The key things riding the dollar last year are now out.” That being said, not all EMFX is equal, clearly. On Monday, the ZAR and TRY - typically two that rally amid global risk-on - were lower, largely on domestic factors (Eskom announcing an intensification of load shedding in ZAR, and Turkey entering technical recession last week for the TRY). In Brazil, however, the BRL rallied on Monday, despite its Vice President expressing his hope that lawmakers would approve pension reform by June, or early Q3 - markets have wanted to see this particular segment of reform out of the way by the Parliamentary recess in July, in order for the new government to show its pro-business credentials.

* GBP: Trades negative against the Buck, after more uncertainty was injected into the Brexit process via the Speaker of the House, who said PM May's MV3 cannot be voted on in its current form, and would need to be materially different from the two previous versions. The news appears negative, however, some commentators have noted that this helps May's position, in the sense that it allows more time to rally support. There is some A list data on the slate for later in the week, as well as a BOE meeting. However, don't expect GBP to be a function of fundamental news ahead of the EU summit next week (and until A50 is extended). Some have noted that UK surprise indices have risen to almost 5-year highs (according to Citi's model), but that has not been driving sterling.

* COMMODITY FX: Ahead of the RBA's meeting minutes, the AUD traded firmer, largely influenced by the constructive risk backdrop. Additionally, some analysts suggest the Aussie is seeing upside based on a continued short-squeeze, which was enough to take AUDUSD back to the 0.71 area. Firmer commodity prices also helped. However, firmer oil prices were not benefiting the NOK, which traded lower against both the USD and the EUR, despite the Norges Bank widely seen lifting rates on Thursday. The CAD also struggled to benefit.

* HAVENS: The Franc briefly breached parity in the run up to the SNB and FOMC, but is still holding steady vs the Eur on the 1.1350 pivot, while the JPY straddles 111.50 in wake of mixed Japanese trade figures and reports suggesting that some BOJ members are not even sure if the 2% inflation target is attainable by 2021, while exports data overnight was also soft. Note also, decent option expiry interest may have hampered trade into the NY cut as 1.1 bn rolled off from 111.55-60 today.

Daily FX Wrap: Dollar fends off pre-FOMC selling, but Pound still beset by Brexit uncertainty
content:
USD

The Greenback is holding up relatively well in the run up to the Fed on Wednesday amidst dovish expectations, centring on lower 2019 dot plots or even none at all, and an early end to the balance sheet run-off. The DXY has also drawn some encouragement from a technical standpoint as the recent low and a chart support level held in again just under 96.400. The index is currently around 96.500 again within a 96.596-376 range.

GBP

In contrast to the Dollar’s resilience, Sterling seems unable to shrug off the ongoing Brexit impasse as UK PM May struggles to garner enough support for the WA to hold a 3rd MV before this week’s EU Summit and avoid asking for more than a short technical extension to Article 50. Indeed, as the clock ticks down to March 29 there has even been talk about an emergency or crisis Summit just a day before, as talks go on here between the Government and DUP, whose backing is seen pivotal to whether the ERG buys into the deal, even though a hard core of the latter are said to be against it no matter what. Cable is just off a marginal new session low circa 1.3213 and Eur/Gbp tested 0.8580+ before topping out. Back to Brexit, the HoC Speaker will make a statement at 15.30GMT, confirming earlier media reports, and possibly about the legal process surrounding multiple votes on the same amendment. Meanwhile, another political commentator suggests a deal with the DUP is almost guaranteed not to be struck this week, and MV3 could now take place next week.

AUD/NZD

The Antipodeans remain in pole position, but have pared more gains vs their US counterpart due to the aforementioned Usd recovery, with the Aud only just clinging to 0.7100 and Nzd easing back towards 0.6860 as the Aussie/Kiwi cross holds just under 1.0350. Ahead, Westpac’s consumer survey for Q1 comes just 2 days before NZ Q4 GDP data, while RBA’s Kent may provide some independent fodder and direction for the Aud.

EUR

Still consolidating on the 1.1300 handle, but unable to test resistance above 1.1350 as the Buck bounced and the headline pair remained in a 1.1320-60 range. No real response to Eurozone trade data of the Buba monthly report that noted downside pressures impacting the German economy.

CHF/CAD/JPY

The Franc briefly breached parity in the run up to the SNB and FOMC, but is still holding steady vs the Eur on the 1.1350 pivot, while the Loonie has slipped towards the bottom of a 1.3300-50 band and the Jpy straddles 111.50 in wake of mixed Japanese trade figures and reports suggesting that some BoJ members are not even sure if the 2% inflation target is attainable by 2021. Note also, decent option expiry interest may have hampered trade  into the NY cut as 1.1 bn rolled off from 111.55-60 today.

EM

The Rub has been a marked regional outperformer on the back of a rebound in Brent prices and bullish Rouble chart signals vs the Usd as it climbed through 64.5000 and tested 6.1500+ levels at one stage.

content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Boeing (BA) – US federal prosecutors are now probing into the development of Boeing’s 737 MAX jets
  • Disney (DIS), Fox (FOXA) – Shareholders of Fox voted for the form of consideration they would like to receive for its acquisition
  • Fidelity National Information Services (FIS), Worldpay (WP) – FIS is to acquire Worldpay for USD 43bln in a cash and stock deal

 

18th March 2019

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – The tech titan’s Apple Watch was able to detect irregular heartbeats according to a large study funded by the co. Elsewhere, Maxwell has filed a patent lawsuit against the co. in regard to allegations it infringed three patents related to walking navigation, NY Times reports. Apple (AAPL) have announced a new iPad Mini (starting at USD 399, USD 529 for WIFI+ Cellular) and iPad Air (starting at USD 499, USD 629 for WIFI+ Cellular). (Newswires/NY Times)
  • Boeing (BA) – US federal prosecutors are now probing into the development of Boeing’s 737 MAX jets, WSJ reports. After retrieving black box data from the fatal Ethiopian Airlines crash that, investigators have determined similarities from the Lion Air crash in 2018. Barron’s magazine writes that the fallout from the incident may last for years as the historic aerospace co. will now need to win back “skittish” customers. Muddy Waters Research tweeted that a Seattle Times article before the Ethiopia Airlines crash showed that the FAA had been over-delegating certification duties to manufacturers, hinting at a drop of standards in the safety/certification process. (WSJ/Newswires/Barron’s)
  • Disney (DIS), Fox (FOXA) – Shareholders of Fox voted for the form of consideration they would like to receive for its acquisition by Disney: 51.57% elected to receive cash; 36.65% elected to receive shares of stock of Disney; 11.79% did not vote. (Newswires)
  • DowDuPont (DWDP) – The chemical co.’s subsidiary Dow Inc. says it plans to launch its share repurchase programme following its separation from DowDuPont. (Newswires)
  • Goldman Sachs (GS) – The bank has had a lawsuit filed against several of its directors by an investor group in regard to the 1MDB scandal. (Newswires)
  • Intel (INTC) – The chipmaker is raising its efforts to mass produce chips that will be 5G compatible, where Qualcomm (QCOM) and MediaTek are its main competitors for Apple (AAPL) orders. (DigiTimes)
  • Pfizer (PFE), Bristol-Myers (BMY) – The two pharma co.s’ Phase 4 AUGUSTUS trial of their Eliquis drug showed promising results. (Newswires)
  • Walmart (WMT) – The retailer’s Japanese unit Seiyu played down speculation that it was mulling a sale of the unit, which last year was reported of being valued at USD 2.69bln-4.48bln. (Newswires)
  • Walmart (WMT), Amazon (AMZN) – Indian regulators are probing Walmart’s Flipkart and Amazon to see if they violated foreign exchange law. (Economic Times)

S&P500

  • Abbott (ABT) – The medtech co.’s COAPT trial, of its MitraClip for treatment of heart failure patients with mitral regurgitation showed promising results. Elsewhere, its MOMENTUM 3 study of the use of a heart pump to treat heart failure met its primary endpoint. (Newswires)
  • Allergan (AGN) – The pharma co. has received FDA approval for its CUTI and CIAI in paediatric patients’ treatment, Avycaz. (Newswires)
  • Altria (MO) – The tobacco co. reported a 55% stake in the cannabis producer Cronos Group as of March 8th, Cronos said it may be desirable to create a new holding company structure in a jurisdiction out of Canada. (Newswires)
  • Boston Scientific (BSX) – The medtech co.’s AF-FICIENT I study of its LUMINIZE Radiofrequency Balloon Catheter for treatment of atrial fibrillation showed promising results. (Newswires)
  • Dominion (D) – The utilities co. has welcomed the state of Connecticut’s contract with itself for the Millstone Power Station, which will provide carbon-free electricity in a contract length of ten years. (Newswires)
  • Edward Lifesciences (EW) – The heart valve focused medtech co.’s PARTNER 3 trail, for its SAPIEN 3 transcatheter aortic valve showed promising results when used in surgery. (Newswires)
  • Fidelity National Information Services (FIS), Worldpay (WP) – FIS is to acquire Worldpay for USD 43bln in a cash and stock deal, where Worldpay shareholders will be entitled to receive 0.9287 FIS shares and USD 11.00 in cash for each share of Worldpay. (Newswires)
  • General Motors (GM) – US President Trump tweeted his dissatisfaction towards GM CEO Mary Berra and GM’s decision to shut down its Ohio plant “when everything else in our country is BOOMING.” (Newswires)
  • Juniper (JNPR) – The networks co. has appointed the Salesforce (CRM) Platform executive Anne DelSanto to its board of directors. (Newswires)
  • Marriott (MAR) – the hotels co. sees EPS at USD 7.65-8.50 by 2021, where it plans to add 275,000-295,000 rooms by 2021 too as part of its three-year growth plan. (Newswires)
  • Medtronic (MDT) – The medtech co.’s Evolut transcatheter aortic valve replacement system for the treatment of aortic stenosis met its primary endpoint. Elsewhere, its TYRX Absorbable Antibacterial Envelope trial, WRAP-IT, for the prevention of infections showed promising results. (Newswires)
  • Newell Brands (NWL) – The home products co. is to sell its Process Solutions unit to a private equity firm to One Rock Capital Partners, where after tax proceeds are estimated at USD 500mln. (Newswires)
  • PepsiCo (PEP) – The beverages co. has made some leadership changes for its LatAm region, where Paula Santilli, currently President of PepsiCo Mexico Foods, has been appointed to CEO, LatAm. (Newswires)
  • Roper Technologies (ROP) – The industrials co. will pay over GBP 400mln for the British visual effects group Foundry. (Sky News)
  • Barron’s magazine writes bullishly on U.S. Steel (X) and Nucor (NUE), citing a revival of US steel manufacturing, and solar stocks First Solar (FSLR) and Canadian Solar (CSIQ), citing a rebound due from a rough 2018. (Barron’s)

NASDAQ

  • Amazon (AMZN) – The retailer has received final approval from North Virginia for its incentive plan to build its HQ2 in the state. (Newswires)
  • Amgen (AMGN) – The pharma co. will carry out a four-year outcome study, VESALIUS-CV, of its cardiovascular treatment Repatha on over 13,000 patients, expected to begin in Q2 2019. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – Price target lowered to USD 187 from USD 205 at BAML over uncertainty over privacy issues. Tigress Financial say the social media’s recent share price weakness presents a buying opportunity. Elsewhere, Facebook has removed over 1.5mln videos of the New Zealand mosque attack, citing the decision as “out of respect for the people affected by this tragedy.” BAML analyst have lowered their price target on the co.(Newswires)
  • Kraft Heinz (KHC) – The packaged foods co. has received a deficiency notice from Nasdaq after not filing its 10-K annual form in time, this has no immediate effect on the listing or trading of the stock. (Newswires)
  • Regeneron (REGN) – The pharma co., alongside Sanofi (SNY), have received EU approval for their cardiovascular disease treatment Praulent. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Deutsche Bank (DB), Commerzbank (CBK GY) – The two German banks have confirmed merger talks. (Newswires)
  • Eldorado Resorts (ERI), Caesars (CZR) – The two resorts/casinos co.s are in preliminary merger talks, this comes after investor Carl Icahn pushed Casers for strategic alternatives such as a sale. (Newswires)
  • PG&E (PCG) – The bankrupt utilities co. is reportedly close to announcing its new CEO, where Bill Johnson is favoured to take the roll. (WSJ)

Downgrades

  • QUEST DIAGNOSTICS (DGX) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OUTPERFORM AT CREDIT SUISSE
  • SOLARWINDS (SWI) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM BUY AT GOLDMAN SACHS

 

Initiations

  • CARS.COM (CARS) RATED NEW NEUTRAL AT GOLDMAN; PT USD 23
  • MOMENTA (MNTA) RATED NEW NEUTRAL AT BTIG
  • WESTERN ASSET MORTGAGE (WMC) RATED NEW MARKET PERFORM AT KBW

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 18th March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Mixed start to the week for Major European Indices [Stoxx 600 +0.1%] following a relatively optimistic lead from Asia
  • A summit between US President Donald Trump and Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping could be delayed to June according to sources
  • Antipodeans outperform as the dollar is generally subdued, GBP choppy ahead of another crucial week for Brexit
  • Amidst conflicting reports, Iraqi Energy minister confirms next OPEC+ JMMC in June; although sources indicate May is also on the cards
  • Looking ahead, highlights include ECB’s Praet & de Guindos Speaking

 

ASIA  

Asian stocks began the week mostly higher after last Friday’s tech-led upside on Wall St, but with early cautiousness observed ahead of the week’s plethora of central bank activity and amid uncertainty with the Trump-Xi summit said to be pushed back to June. ASX 200 (+0.3%) eked marginal gains as underperformance in telecoms and financials offset some of the commodity-driven strength in the Australian bourse, while the Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) was underpinned by a weaker currency following mixed data in which Trade Surplus topped estimates but both Exports and Imports contracted more than expected. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+2.5%) were both positive after the PBoC increased its liquidity efforts and as mainland China shrugged off an early whimsical tone caused by uncertainty from the delay of the Trump-Xi summit. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively unchanged with demand dampened by the gains in riskier assets and with downside also restricted by the BoJ’s presence in the market.

A summit between US President Donald Trump and Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping could be delayed to June according to sources who noted they will not be able to finalise an agreement by April. In related news, a source reportedly suggested that there was a divergence within the Trump administration regarding the deal with China. (SCMP/Twitter)

Chinese President Xi is set to visit Europe this week in efforts to bolster trade relationships. The Chinese President will travel to France, Italy and Monaco from March 21st to 26th; according to Chinese Foreign Ministry Spokesman Lu Kang. (Newswires/Xinhua)

China's assistant Commerce Minister says China's foreign trade situation is becoming more uncertain and more complicated. (Newswires) 

PBoC injected CNY 60bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7088 (Prev. 6.7167)

Japanese Trade Balance Total (JPY)(Feb) 339.0B vs. Exp. 310.2B (Prev. -1415.2B, Rev. -1415.6B). (Newswires) Japanese Exports (Feb) Y/Y -1.2% vs. Exp. -0.9% (Prev. -8.4%) Japanese Imports (Feb) Y/Y -6.7% vs. Exp. -5.8% (Prev. -0.6%, Rev. -0.8%)

US

Iran's President Rouhani says Tehran will file legal case against US officials for imposing sanctions which are 'crimes against humanity'. (Newswires)

UK/EU            

UK PM May received backing by some staunch Brexiteers after she personally lobbied MPs but still remained significantly short of the number she needs to win a vote this week. Furthermore, it was separately reported that 40 Tory rebels told PM May they would only support her deal if she quits as PM. (Times/BuzzFeed)

Various UK ministers suggested PM May could cancel this week's 3rd Brexit vote if there is not enough support. In related news, former UK Foreign Minister Johnson called for a delay in the 3rd Brexit vote and said it is not too late to get a real change regarding backstop. (Telegraph)

The DUP reportedly want a seat in trade negotiations with the EU in exchange for supporting PM May and there were also reports citing senior DUP figures that they held constructive Brexit talks with ministers, while sources close to the DUP also said that the regulatory alignment offer may have won over the DUP. (Newswires/Telegraph/Times)

UK opposition Labour Party leader Corbyn is to hold cross-party talks in an attempt to solve the Brexit deadlock, while he warned that PM May cannot keep bringing back an unchanged deal. Furthermore, there were reports that the labour leader signalled that his party would back an amendment aimed at securing a second Brexit referendum, set to be tabled this week. (Sky News/Guardian)

UK Eurosceptic Lawmaker Redwood states that a lot of people are still opposed to UK PM May's deal, which goes beyond the ERG. (Newswires)

30 Eurosceptic Tory MP's are still opposed to UK PM May's deal & ERG calls over the weekend suggests that positions have hardened; Telegraph's Swinford. (Twitter)

A senior Cabinet minister says the chance of a Meaningful Vote 3 passing is "Not yet above 50% but heading in the right direction”, according to Times Columnist Matt Chorley. (Twitter)

German Foreign Minister Maas says it is worth having another round of talks before it comes to a hard Brexit. (Newswires)

German Chancellery Chief says the issue of a delay is not uncontroversial amongst EU states, and that they cannot rule out that Italy or another country may thwart the delay; BILD. Following this, an Official stated that Italy has no plans to block an Article 50 extension. (Newswires)

A Senior EU Diplomat said last week that the EU was resigned to not having clarity from the UK and PM May by this Wednesday, according to Daily Telegraph's Europe Editor Peter Foster. (Twitter)

British Chambers of Commerce cut its 2019 growth forecast to 1.2% from 1.3% and cut 2020 growth forecast cut to 1.3% from 1.5%, while it sees UK business investment this year to decline by most in a decade of 1.0% Y/Y due to Brexit. (Newswires)

EU & China are to agree to conclude bilateral investment pact in 2020., Draft Statement for April Summit

- Are to agree to list main barriers to trade by this summer, and to set removal deadlines by 2020

- To commit to begin negotiations on industrial subsidies, and a new set of guidelines for government-supported export credits.

Following this, Chinese Governments top diplomat Wang Yi says competition with Europe may be inevitable. (Newswires)

 

Moody’s affirmed Italy at Baa3. (Newswires)

S&P raised Portugal sovereign rating from BBB- to BBB; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed Switzerland at AAA; Outlook Stable and affirmed Norway at AAA; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

Russia President Putin stated that Japan-Russia peace treaty talks need a short rest if Japan is unwilling to exit security cooperation pact with US concerning disputed islands. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Mixed start to the week for major European indices [Stoxx 600 +0.1%] following a relatively optimistic lead from Asia where China outperformed amid liquidity efforts by the PBoC coupled with the Chinese government’s steps to enhance the country’s economy. UK’s FTSE 100 (+0.6%) is the marked outperformer and major beneficiary from the surge in base metal prices with heavyweight miners all sitting comfortably at the top of the index (Rio Tinto +2.5%, Anglo American +2.3%, Antofagasta +2.1%, Glencore +1.8%). Sector-wise, material names initially outperformed (for the aforementioned reason) but was later overtaken by financial names ahead of a plethora of central bank rate decision including FOMC and BOE. Financial names may also feel support from the Deutschebank (+3.1%)/Commerzbank (+5.8%) saga, with the latest reports confirming merger talks between the two banks after the German government approved the tie-up, although, German union Verdi warned that merger could put up to 30k jobs at risk, to which the government replied that jobs at stake are being examined. On a broader front for European banks, GS notes that the sector has been amongst the weakest performers in the Stoxx 600 YTD as the banks continue to battle with concerns over long term growth. In terms of strategy, GS noted that Japanese banks trades at an even lower multiple than the European, but the latest TLTRO move (although positive for sector liquidity) “further erodes the competitive advantage of European banks”. GS is taking a neutral stance on the European equity market over the next three months.

Boeing (BA) - the US Transportation Department are reportedly probing FAA approval of the 737 Max, according to WSJ citing sources (WSJ)

FX

AUD/NZD – Off overnight highs, but the Aussie and Kiwi remain elevated and ahead of their G10 counterparts on a combination of renewed risk appetite, short covering and for the former also a supply-related rise in iron ore prices following further production problems for Brazil’s Vale. Aud/Usd has extended its rebound to 0.7100+ and Nzd/Usd to around 0.6875 as the Aud/Nzd cross pivots 1.0350 ahead of Westpac’s NZ Q1 consumer survey later today and Q4 GDP on Wednesday. In terms of options, large expiries in Nzd/Usd run off later, including 1 bn at 0.6825 and 1.5 bn at 0.6925.

GBP – In contrast to the outperformance down under noted above, the Pound has handed back gains vs a generally soft Dollar and weakened relative to the Euro amidst ongoing Brexit uncertainty after last week’s string of UK Parliamentary votes, as PM May strives to drum up DUP support for the current Withdrawal Agreement in the hope that this may entice enough of the ERG to back the deal in time for a pre-EU Summit 3rd MV. Cable has backed off from another 1.3300 venture to sub-1.3250 and Eur/Gbp has bounced to around 0.8570 vs circa 0.8510 at one stage, with a hefty 1.7 bn option expiry at the 0.8500 strike now looking pretty safe.

EUR – Aside from benefiting from Sterling’s Brexit angst, the single currency has taken advantage of the aforementioned Greenback weakness post-recent soft if not quite downbeat US data and pre-FOMC. Indeed, the headline pair has rebounded further from early March lows (in wake of the dovish ECB) to establish a firmer footing above 1.1300 and briefly touched 1.1350, with the next bullish targets at 1.1367 and 1.1373 (100 DMA and 50% Fib of the 1.1570-1.1177 move respectively).

CHF/CAD/JPY – All narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, as the Franc attempts to break resistance at the psychological parity level in the run up to the SNB and FOMC, but holds steady vs the Eur on the 1.1350 pivot, while the Loonie sits midway between 1.3300-50 ahead of Canadian securities data for January and the Jpy straddles 111.50 in wake of mixed Japanese trade figures and reports suggesting that some BoJ members are not even sure if the 2% inflation target is attainable by 2021. Note also, decent option expiry interest could be influential given 1.1 bn rolling off from 111.55-60 today.

FIXED INCOME

It was relatively abrupt and did roughly coincide with a downturn in EU equities, but not really enough to suggest asset-reallocation, so it looks like the recovery in Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries from earlier session lows was prompted by something else or a mixture of factors. Given the UK benchmark’s outperformance and especially strong bounce from worst levels to trade 30 ticks above the previous 126.90 close, Brexit seems a valid supportive impulse as the clock ticks down to either another MV or returning to Brussels to request an A 50 extension, or more likely both. Meanwhile, its German equivalent has been 22 ticks above par at 164.36 and a bit less hampered by outperformance across the Eurozone periphery after positive ratings reviews for Italy and Portugal in particular, and USTs have nudged fresh, albeit marginal overnight highs awaiting the Fed on Wednesday.

COMMODITIES

WTI (-0.4%) and Brent (-0.2%) futures are marginally lower as participants digest the latest from the meeting of the OPEC cartel in Baku, although there seems to be some discrepancy as to when the next JMMC meeting will take place. Energy futures saw a marginal leg lower, with WTI losing more ground below its 100 WMA (USD 58.46/bbl) after sources stated that the JMMC panel recommended no meeting in April, but the Kazakh Energy Minister said nothing was set in stone. Furthermore, the Iraqi Energy Minister reportedly confirmed that the next JMMC meeting will take place in June, however sources later came out with a May meeting in Riyadh. Prices were little affected by developments over the weekend wherein the Saudi Energy Minister stated that the Kingdom’s March and April output is to drop to around 9.8mln BPD vs. February level of 10.09mln BPD (January 10.24mln BPD). Recalling some comments from last week, a Saudi official stated that March an April output is to be “well below” 10mln BPD. Saudi did however mention that OPEC’s job from rebalancing is far from over whilst signalling that output curbs need to be extended to H2 2019.

Elsewhere, the metals complex is bolstered by a pullback in the Greenback with gold reclaiming the USD 1300/oz level and breaching its 50 DMA to the upside at 1304.10 whilst copper prices benefit from the overall risk appetite. Finally, Dalian iron ore futures surged over 3% on supply concerns after a Brazilian court ordered Vale halts operations at another mine and as the miner suggested a 12mln ton decline in annual output due to dam suspensions.

Saudi’s February production stood at 10.09mln BPD vs. 10.24mln BPD in January, according to sources. (Newswires) 

Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih said OPEC and its allies remain ready to continue monitoring supply and demand and doing what we have to do in H2 to keep the markets balanced. (Newswires)

- Says we are not under pressure from the US to increase supply, adding that they are guided by oil inventories and will not change course until a decline in inventory is observed

- Needs to consider if there is a need for a OPEC+ April meeting

- There is a general consensus regarding the need for an extension of the cuts, is confident that oil producers will reach full conformity with the cuts and even exceed them in the upcoming weeks

Russia Energy Minister Novak said that a decision will be made on the future steps of an oil output by May-June, while he also commented that Russia has begun lowering oil output as part of the OPEC+ agreement. (Newswires)

Iraqi Energy Minister confirmed that the next OPEC+ JMMC will take place in June. Following this, the Kazakh oil minister says that no final decision has been made regarding the April meeting and the Saudi proposal will be considered later. While sources state that OPEC+ are planning JMMC meeting in Riyadh in May. (Newswires)

subject: BREXIT ANALYSIS: SEB’s View, EU Leaders on Article 50 Extension & Key Dates
content:
*LEADERS' VIEWS

French President Macron: Seen as the most resistant to making a delay easy; determined to impose tough conditions on an extension and seek a delay of up to 21 months.

German Chancellor Merkel: Regarded as the most open to granting an extension without multiple conditions.

Irish PM Varadkar: As the Irish border is preventing PM May’s deal passing commons, which gives them disproportionate influence in discussions.

Spanish PM Sanchez: Despite the government stating they see the Gibraltar issue as closed, there is some concern in Westminster that it may resurface as the cost of an extension.

Poland's Morawiecki/Hungary's Orban/Italy's Conte: These three leaders are often the most likely to cause trouble to the European Consensus, but this is seen as unlikely. Although, Farage and other Eurosceptic's vowed to lobby member states hoping that one will veto an extension. 

 

*SEB'S VIEW

SEB’s view is that all decisions made by the EU must take into account the fact the member countries wish for the UK to remain in the EU or at least for cooperation to be as close as possible. Therefore, the EU would have no major objections to an extension; as the possibility remains for the UK to entirely reassess its position.

 

*KEY DATES

March 18th - MPs to discuss Meaning Vote 3

March 19th/20th – Parliamentary vote on Withdrawal Agreement

March 21st-22nd – EU Summit

March 29th – UK Withdrawal Date

May 23rd-26th – European Parliament Elections

June 30th – Final date for Brexit, after this the UK must hold EU elections

July 1st – European Parliament is Selected

December 31st 2020 – Transition Period ends under the Withdrawal Agreement

Note: these date are subject to change.

subject: Bunds: probing below parity ahead of the EU stock opens
content: The 10 year German benchmark is succumbing to a bit more selling pressure after starting Monday’s Eurex session on the front foot, but only managing to extend gains to 11 ticks at 164.25 before losing momentum, and just slipped into negative territory and a marginal new 164.08 low. A broad upturn in risk sentiment is weighing on core debt, though for now at least underlying bids ahead of 164.00 are holding relatively firm. Only Eurozone trade data to come, plus the Buba monthly bulletin and a speech by ECB’s Praet.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 18th March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian stocks began the week mostly higher after last Friday’s tech-led upside on Wall St, China outperformed
  • A summit between US President Donald Trump and Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping could be delayed to June according to sources
  • UK PM May received backing by some staunch Brexiteers after she personally lobbied MPs but still remained significantly short of the number she needs to win a vote this week
  • In FX markets, price action was relatively quiet amid a lack of overnight catalysts and with participants tentative ahead of the upcoming central bank policy meetings
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Bundesbank Monthly Report and ECB’s Praet

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian stocks began the week mostly higher after last Friday’s tech-led upside on Wall St, but with early cautiousness observed ahead of the week’s plethora of central bank activity and amid uncertainty with the Trump-Xi summit said to be pushed back to June. ASX 200 (+0.3%) eked marginal gains as underperformance in telecoms and financials offset some of the commodity-driven strength in the Australian bourse, while the Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) was underpinned by a weaker currency following mixed data in which Trade Surplus topped estimates but both Exports and Imports contracted more than expected. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.4%) were both positive after the PBoC increased its liquidity efforts and as mainland China shrugged off an early whimsical tone caused by uncertainty from the delay of the Trump-Xi summit. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively unchanged with demand dampened by the gains in riskier assets and with downside also restricted by the BoJ’s presence in the market.

A summit between US President Donald Trump and Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping could be delayed to June according to sources who noted they will not be able to finalise an agreement by April. In related news, a source reportedly suggested that there was a divergence within the Trump administration regarding the deal with China. (SCMP/Twitter)

Chinese President Xi is set to visit Europe this week in efforts to bolster trade relationships. The Chinese President will travel to France, Italy and Monaco from March 21st to 26th; according to Chinese Foreign Ministry Spokesman Lu Kang. (Newswires/Xinhua) 

PBoC injected CNY 60bln via 7-day reverse repos). (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7088 (Prev. 6.7167)

Japanese Trade Balance Total (JPY)(Feb) 339.0B vs. Exp. 310.2B (Prev. -1415.2B, Rev. -1415.6B). (Newswires) Japanese Exports (Feb) Y/Y -1.2% vs. Exp. -0.9% (Prev. -8.4%) Japanese Imports (Feb) Y/Y -6.7% vs. Exp. -5.8% (Prev. -0.6%, Rev. -0.8%)

UK/EU

UK PM May received backing by some staunch Brexiteers after she personally lobbied MPs but still remained significantly short of the number she needs to win a vote this week. Furthermore, it was separately reported that 40 Tory rebels told PM May they would only support her deal if she quits as PM. (Times/BuzzFeed)

Various UK ministers suggested PM May could cancel this week's 3rd Brexit vote if there is not enough support. In related news, former UK Foreign Minister Johnson called for a delay in the 3rd Brexit vote and said it is not too late to get a real change regarding backstop. (Telegraph)

The DUP reportedly want a seat in trade negotiations with the EU in exchange for supporting PM May and there were also reports citing senior DUP figures that they held constructive Brexit talks with ministers, while sources close to the DUP also said that the regulatory alignment offer may have won over the DUP. (Newswires/Telegraph/Times)

UK opposition Labour Party leader Corbyn is to hold cross-party talks in an attempt to solve the Brexit deadlock, while he warned that PM May cannot keep bringing back an unchanged deal. Furthermore, there were reports that the labour leader signalled that his party would back an amendment aimed at securing a second Brexit referendum, set to be tabled this week. (Sky News/Guardian)

EU ambassadors were reportedly told that there is nothing in Article 50 to prevent multiple extensions but if UK has not held European elections by 23 May, it will not be able to extend again beyond 1 July. Furthermore, it was also reported that the European Council cannot attach conditions to an extension of Article 50 according to Guardian’s Daniel Boffey. (Newswires/Twitter)

British Chambers of Commerce cut its 2019 growth forecast to 1.2% from 1.3% and cut 2020 growth forecast cut to 1.3% from 1.5%, while it sees UK business investment this year to decline by most in a decade of 1.0% Y/Y due to Brexit. (Newswires)

UK Rightmove House Prices (Mar) M/M 0.4% (Prev. 0.7%). (Newswires) UK Rightmove House Prices (Mar) Y/Y -0.8% (Prev. 0.2%)

S&P raised Portugal sovereign rating from BBB- to BBB; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed Switzerland at AAA; Outlook Stable and affirmed Norway at AAA; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

 

FX

In FX markets, price action was relatively quiet amid a lack of overnight catalysts and with participants tentative ahead of the upcoming central bank policy meetings including FOMC and BoE. This initially provided DXY with a breather from its recent data-driven downtrend in which Industrial and Manufacturing Production numbers on Friday added to the ongoing run of soft releases ranging from jobs numbers to inflation figures, and therefore further supporting a patient view by the Fed. However, the reprieve was short-lived with the greenback later pressured amid the gradual improvement in risk sentiment which underpinned antipodeans to push AUD/USD above 0.7100, while USD/JPY was also higher but with upside capped by recent USD-woes and large option expiries totalling over 1bln at around 111.55-60 for today’s New York cut. Elsewhere, EUR/USD was relatively flat at the 1.1300 handle and GBP/USD was constrained by resistance around 1.3300 with participants bracing themselves for more potential Brexit-related impulses with parliament to possibly vote on PM May’s deal again this week prior to the European Council meeting, although some suggested this could be cancelled if there is not enough support.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed overnight with WTI crude futures lacklustre after running out of steam having recently hit multi-month highs just shy of the USD 59.00/bbl level and with Brent flatlining around USD 67.00/bbl. In addition, participants await comments from the latest OPEC and Non-OPEC monitoring committee today, while the rhetoric ahead of the meeting has shown some differing views with Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih adamant OPEC needs to stay on course regarding the supply cut deal, while his Russian counterpart Novak suggested a decision on future steps by May-June. Elsewhere, gold was flat as a lack of demand for safe havens was counterbalanced by a lacklustre greenback, while copper benefited from the improved risk appetite as well as gains in Dalian iron futures on supply concerns after a Brazilian court ordered for Vale to halt operations at another mine and as the miner suggested a 12mln tons decline in annual output due to dam suspensions. 

Baker Hughes Rig Count (15 Mar): total rigs -1 at 1026, oil rigs -1 at 833, gas rigs unchanged at 193. (Newswires)

Saudi’s February production stood at 10.09mln BPD vs. 10.24mln BPD in January, according to sources. (Newswires) 

Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih said OPEC and its allies remain ready to continue monitoring supply and demand and doing what we have to do in H2 to keep the markets balanced. (Newswires)

Russia Energy Minister Novak said that a decision will be made on the future steps of an oil output by May-June, while he also commented that Russia has begun lowering oil output as part of the OPEC+ agreement. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Russia President Putin stated that Japan-Russia peace treaty talks need a short rest if Japan is unwilling to exit security cooperation pact with US concerning disputed islands. (Newswires) 

US

Treasuries caught a bid on Friday, in a session influenced by both flows and macro themes, where against the grain, equities made healthy gains. The T-plex gained momentum going into the US equity open, with CTA short covering and real money and hedge fund buying kickstarting the rally, also supported by a gloomy outlook from the BoJ on top of North Korea woes, and was exacerbated by the both disappointing Empire Manufacturing survey and Manufacturing/IP data. Once equities opened in the green, Treasuries lost their tailwind as traders took their profits. The curve flattened going into settlement with the belly’s yields falling the most, where the 2s/10s flattened by 2bps. However, spreads in the belly to long-end still remain at their steepest levels in months. US T-note futures (M9) settled 8+ ticks at higher 122-31.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks trade positive but with cautiousness seen after reports of a further Trump-Xi summit delay
content:
Asia stocks begin the week with cautious gains as momentum from last Friday’s tech-led upside on Wall St. somewhat faded ahead of this week’s plethora of central bank activity and due to trade uncertainty with the Trump-Xi summit said to be pushed back to June. As such, ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) were mixed fore most of early trade with underperformance in telecoms and financials weighing on the Australian bourse, while stocks in Japan remained afloat as participants digested mixed data in which Trade Surplus topped estimates but both Exports and Imports contracted more than expected. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.0%) are positive after the PBoC increased its liquidity efforts and as mainland China eventually recovered from an early whimsical tone caused by uncertainty from the delay of the Trump-Xi summit.

In FX markets, price action is uneventful amid a lack of catalysts and with participants tentative ahead of the upcoming central bank policy meetings including FOMC and BoE. This has provided the DXY with a breather from its recent data-driven downtrend in which Industrial and Manufacturing Production numbers on Friday added to the ongoing run of soft releases ranging from jobs numbers to inflation figures, and therefore supporting a patient view by the Fed. The greenback’s major counterparts are relatively uneventful with EUR/USD flat at the 1.1300 handle and with GBP/USD contained by resistance around 1.3300 as participants brace themselves for more potential Brexit-related impulses with parliament to possibly vote on PM May’s deal again this week prior to the European Council meeting, although some suggested this could be cancelled if there is not enough support. Elsewhere, the positive risk tone has provided a mild lift for antipodeans, and to a greater extent for JPY-crosses, while USD/JPY is also higher but with upside capped by recent USD-woes and with large option expiries totalling over 1bln at around 111.55-60 for today’s New York cut.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are unchanged with demand dampened by the gains in riskier assets, although downside is also restricted by the BoJ’s presence in the market.
